captions.text: Just Like Other Animals presents
The Batman syndrome – genitals versus brains
Hi, you are watching Just Like Animals, the programme on the origin of people.
Your today's hosts are boa constrictor Gaddafi and his human substitute Zhenya Timonova.
Why is everyone so found of Batman? Probably because there are more similarities between humans and bats than taught by the great Darwin.
Zoologists at Syracuse University (led by Dr. Scott Pitnick) analyzed 334 species of bats.
And they came to a fascinating conclusion. Bat species can be monogamous or polygamous.
The monogamous ones form pairs, while the polygamous are prone to promiscuity and indiscriminate copulation.
Well, indiscriminate... In fact, female bats have a very distinct criterion that guides their choice of sexual partners.
It's quite simple: the size of the male's genitals. And bats have huge genitals, up to 8,5% of their body mass.
If a man of 80 kg had the same size, his genitals would weight about 7 kg.
I can't imagine that!
And that looks really impressive. Especially because bats have the same structure of the male genitals as humans, the so-called penis pendulum.
Now picture the male hanging upside down with his penis pendulum, wrapped in wings for thermal insulation. Then, a female drops by.
And he says to her: - Ha-cha! Eight percent, baby! - Oh, you're the real Batman! And then things happen.
Not all bat species have such luck. Only those that practice promiscuity.
The more sexual partners for females, the bigger male genitals.
Dr. Pitnick should have ended his research on this optimistic note. But unfortunately he went ahead and came to a conclusion that ruined everything.
In bat species with promiscuous females, there is an inverse correlation between the size of male genitals and the size of their brains.
The males with bigger genitals have smaller brains.
And this, disappointing for some of us, fact has a logical explanation.
Polygamous females force their mating partners to fight sperm wars.
Every male wants females to raise his offspring, and not that of other participating males.
Victory in this war is determined by quantity and quality of the sperm. And that requires very powerful genitals.
Male bats are forced into a real arms race. And victory in this arms race comes at a very steep price.
Functional testicular tissue is very expensive, i.e. metabolically costly to develop and maintain.
Muscle, bone or skin tissue is cheap and can be developed and increased much easier.
But the testicular parenchyma and the brain tissue require significant metabolic investments.
Therefore, male bats have to choose where to invest primarily - in their sexual or intellectual development.
The size of genitals doesn't matter for the females in monogamous species. They are looking for a partner with a great personality.
And the great personality in the bat world is determined by the brain size.
The bigger your brains, the more flexible and adaptive your behaviour, the better your coordination and spatial orientation.
That's why having a big brain is not only sad, but also useful.
The theory of limited resources and metabolic trade-offs was confirmed by another scientific study of the Onthophagus nigriventris beetles.
Females of Onthophagus also mate with multiple males and practice sexual selection.
Males have two weapons in their struggle for females: testicles and horns.
Horns are required to push away other males, and testicles to transfer as many genes as possible to females.
So, inhuman scientists prevented males from developing horns by cauterizing in larvae the area of proliferating cells.
And these larvae grew into adult beetles without horns. But they developed such an incredible testicles!
Another group of larvae had less luck, as scientists prevented them from developing testicles. And these beetles got huge horns.
This is one of the fundamental principles of ontogeny. To become superior in one area, one has to sacrifice something else.
So, guys, if you think you are superior in a certain area, please, don't show off that.
There will always be a girl who will prefer exactly the opposite.
We were Just Like Other Animals. Bye.
We can't film this episode, as I have to show how the bat does it. But my hands are tied.
And he says: - Ha-cha! 8,5 centimetres, baby!
What centimetres? 8,5 percent.
And she says to him: - What a loser!
